chunks.original_text: 或抱出寝帏，儿见天日，常以仰笑，口出紫光，上连天口，甘露如绳，直注儿口； 玉女散花，以拂儿身。 神乌停空，张翼蔽日，香官扬烟，以熏宫中。 尔时，重光三岁能言，声闻百步，常乐独坐，不须人抱。 年至四岁，独言独笑，谈及世表。 年至七岁，不学而知，遐思远视，身边有光，照耀一室。 坐立如山，行如龙步，侧卧东首，四肢半伸，绀发翠眉，目开日角，光含紫映，方口圆鼻，耳长五寸，三门成就，齿白齐密，足三十六数，唇色如丹，方颡高准，人中四起，长十二分。 阔额平正，玉枕如星，发不参差，柔软光泽。 项负三约，四乳方肘，阔胸微偃，心处深厚，臂圆煦直，垂手过膝。 爪坚色红，常有光明。 掌中有华文，三道通达，手心色紫，指长六寸。 脐中深圆，□有伏骨，双靥骈胁，腹生白子。 膊骨方直，藏踝不见。 足跌微偃，筋脉不露。 跖底平满，圆文日轮。 爪根深下，指端微起。 肤容细软，充满香洁。 青骨素髓，五藏莲花。 紫胃筋肠，食不全粒。 顾盻回身，坐立平正。 年至十九，形长一丈，声响如钟，韵惊尘飞。 遥闻十方常有紫虚盖其头上，而止之处，无有霜雪，和气调平，风不狂勃，甘雨微津。 温仁忠恕，忍辱慈顺。 仰观云天，善明经纬。
chunks.translated_text:
At times when he was carried from his bed curtains, the child would see the sky and sun, always laughing upward, his mouth emitting purple radiance that rose to the heavens like a cord, while sweet dew descended in strands straight into his mouth. Jade maidens scattered flowers to brush his body. Divine birds hovered in the air, spreading their wings to shade the sun, while fragrant officials wafted incense to perfume the palace.

By the age of three, *Double Radiance* could speak, his voice carrying a hundred paces, and he delighted in sitting alone, no longer needing to be held. At four, he laughed and conversed in solitude, his words transcending the mundane world. By seven, he knew without learning, his thoughts profound and gaze far-reaching, a light about him illuminating the entire chamber. He sat and stood as steadfast as a mountain, walked with the stride of a dragon, and when lying on his side, his head to the east, his limbs half-extended. His hair was dark blue, his brows emerald; his eyes opened wide at the temples, their light suffused with purple. His mouth was square, his nose rounded, his ears five inches long, with three perfect curves. His teeth were white and even, thirty-six in number, his lips red as cinnabar. His broad forehead was level, his cheekbones high, his philtrum marked by four ridges, twelve *fen* in length. His jade-like nape bore a star-like prominence, his hair neither tangled nor uneven, soft and lustrous. His neck bore three folds, his four nipples aligned with his elbows, his chest broad and slightly arched, his heart’s region deep and full. His arms were round and straight, his hands hanging past his knees, his nails firm and red, perpetually aglow. His palms bore floral patterns, three lines running clearly, their centers purple, his fingers six inches long. His navel was deep and round, with a hidden bone beneath; his cheeks dimpled, his flanks smooth, his abdomen marked by white moles. His shoulder bones were square and straight, his ankles concealed. His insteps were slightly arched, sinews and veins unseen, the soles of his feet full and level, their patterns like sun wheels. His toenails were deeply set, their tips slightly raised. His skin was fine and soft, suffused with fragrance and purity. His bones were blue, his marrow white, his five organs like lotus blossoms. His stomach and intestines were purple, and he ate but half-grains. Whether turning his gaze or shifting his body, he sat and stood with perfect poise.

By nineteen, he stood a full *zhang* in height, his voice resonant as a bell, its tones startling the dust to flight. From afar, a purple void canopy perpetually hovered above his head, and wherever he dwelled, frost and snow never fell. The air was harmonious and mild, winds never raged, and gentle rains fell in due measure. He was warm, benevolent, loyal, and forgiving, enduring insults with compassion and humility. Gazing at the clouds and sky, he discerned the warp and weft of the Dao with clarity.

chunks.original_text: 一切伎艺，不习而工。 幽通至极，预知未然。 父王珍之，大集群臣，议定禅祚。 三让不受。 尔时，五岳响应，虚鸣万岁。 嘉祥毕集，幽明符会。 苦不得已，然始受位。 治民事天，弘道安世，正化无为，不劳人心。 贵德尚善，不令而从。 恩流孤弱，惠及昆虫，人神交归，异类群睦。 每以秋冬，天降甘露，五色之云，以旋日月。 城阙不闭，郊境无防，四海通同，万邦归一。 嘉禾瑞草，合根离颖。 一树十枝，随时四熟。 仙娥布野，荣绢亘原，络织成文，以充衣裳。 盐池醴泉，随处而出，灵芝夜光，遍挺园苑。 神禽奇兽，驯狎墙庑。 麟凤群萃，晨夕和鸣。

All arts and skills he mastered without study. His profound communion reached its utmost, foreknowing all that had yet to unfold. At that moment, the Five Peaks echoed in response, and the void resounded with myriad cries of "Long live the king!" Auspicious omens assembled in full, the unseen and manifest harmonizing as one. With great reluctance, he at last accepted the throne.

He governed the people and served Heaven, propagating the Dao to pacify the world. His governance was upright yet effortless, never taxing the hearts of the people. He esteemed virtue and exalted goodness, so that all followed without command. His benevolence flowed to the orphaned and weak, his kindness extended even to insects. Each autumn and winter, sweet dew descended from the heavens, and five-colored clouds encircled the sun and moon. City gates stood unbarred, borders required no defense. Salt pools and sweet springs welled forth wherever needed. Glowing lingzhi and night-shining herbs flourished throughout the gardens. chunks.original_text: 尔时，有黑水之北，牂羝之狄，斜通河源，雪山之阳，与杂畜之戎，性狡难狎，阴生奸计，闻王善政，不用戎威，相率兴兵，来入王国。 始到雪山之东，羊马灾厉，羝戎疾病，群鬼露形，杀灭戎狄，十分遗七。 中路自悔，跪拜叩伏。 王知其逆心，固不加伐，任其进退。 尔时，大王遍勅国内而作是言：边戎无知，忽怀逆心。 天已罚之，即时自翻。 刀不任进，天下万兆不须惊疑。 我若无道，天必丧我。 三日之中，边疆报国，云贼已退。 是时，群戎复归，其兵昏气，天之十丧其八，瘥疠由兴，灾殃未殄，边陬恐怖，群聚相谓。 享人祷天，灾气转盛。 荒戎之中有一主者，微辨世事，向诸众等而作是言：大国之主，德合於天，修道守正，志不邪偏。 万福扶持，百神守卫。 我等云何相率兴兵而恃上善？ 我国遭灾祥，必由於此。 我当急告邻近诸王，严装所须，速往辞谢。 是时，边戎一百二十五落戎狄之主将诸侍从八万四千人，俱乘白象，赍香花璎络，驰入大国，屏气玉阙，负揭琛赂，肘伏王前，抽膊求哀，劈准流血，拔发如蓬，自扑纷纷，遍体青肿。 兽鸣鸟噪，不可悉解。 强人重译，悔过谢愆，而作是言：我等边隅不治正朔，三才浊气，二象丑形，杂类之种，不识恩美。 虽日有生，实非正气，忽起凶顽，率心不义，而兴兽心，尘秽大国。 群聚未久，已遭天罚，荒陬殇夭，十分丧八。 毒气未休，故犹兴盛。 让者以为反逆，上天纵毒，享人梼祀，转加增甚。 敢从大天求乞哀愍。 言毕自扑，披发悲号。 大王告勅：我承有道之君，系统天下，唯善是履，不务其余。 犹不自哀，云何哀汝？ 我於万物受同一子，未曾偏党，乃至幽冥，亦复如是。 汝生逆心，来向我者，我身不知，付之於天。 我无情而责汝，天无心而伐汝。 汝身受罚，如仰唾天，不离其身； 如仰射天，箭还自中。 自然之道，理无差也。 汝等所赍香花璎络，非我所珍。 我此国中，唯修道德。 及以谷帛、颈珠、璎络，邪俗严身，非正所贵，转重累物，外滞尘滓。 何以故？ 此名外饰，故不足珍。 我此国中一切人民尽用忍辱、退让精进，俭约以为严身之具，以道德戒行为诸香花，不须汝之所有。 尔时，诸戎见大国之王不受其献，恐畏无福，灾害不消，悲泣相顾而作是言：大王不受我献，或恐熑薄。 我等大众各以白象奉上大王，以求哀愍。 大王动言：璎络宝珠，尚非我贵，况於白象，腥躁臭处水草巨大，又须看牧，为我国累。 龙凤轻妙，吾尚不须。 时诸阴戎烦冤懊恼，自拔头发，悲泣而言：大王不受我献。 我身无福，定不免灾，不如自杀以远此祸。 大王勅言：夫求福者空心奉道。 身心既空，道亦虚无。 以空虚故，则无祸患。 既无祸患，名为福德。 又求福者，无希无望。 汝所献者，诚有希望，故我不受希望之献。 我此国中诸贤良等常以善心而自严身，不以缨络、白象为求福也。 大王又言：我此国中，唯当奉行无上大道，余无所求。 诸戎当知，诸求福者，心不邪偏，平等一行，不顺利，不违害，亦不变祸为福，亦不恃福，故能无祸。 何以故？ 恶不胜善，凶自成吉，祸自变灭，亦不见福。 汝欲求福，所避祸者，是汝颠倒，不达祸福，心生背向。 何以故？ 祸福同门，根於虚无。
chunks.translated_text:
At that time, beyond the Black Waters to the north, among the Zang and Di tribes of the snowy highlands—where the river’s source winds slantwise and the sun shines upon the southern face of the Snow Mountains—there dwelt the mixed-herd Rong, a people of cunning nature and untamable disposition. Secretly they hatched a treacherous scheme, and hearing of the king’s virtuous governance, how he ruled without martial might, they mustered their forces and marched upon his kingdom.

No sooner had they reached the eastern slopes of the Snow Mountains than their sheep and horses sickened and died; the Di and Rong fell prey to plague. Ghosts materialized in broad daylight, slaughtering the barbarian hordes until only seven in ten remained. Midway through their march, the survivors repented in terror, falling to their knees in prostration.

The king, though aware of their treacherous intent, refused to strike, allowing them to advance or retreat as they chose. He issued a decree throughout his realm: “The border tribes, ignorant and rebellious, have harbored treachery in their hearts. Heaven has already punished them, and they have turned back of their own accord. No blade need be drawn; let the myriad people of the realm remain untroubled. If I were without the Dao, Heaven would surely cast me down.”

Within three days, word came from the frontier: the invaders had withdrawn. Yet as the tribes retreated, their armies were enveloped in a miasma of death. Heaven had claimed eight in ten of their number; pestilence and plague now raged unchecked. The borderlands trembled in fear, and the people gathered in dread, murmuring among themselves. They offered sacrifices to the spirits and prayed to Heaven, but the calamity only worsened.

Among the barbarian tribes, there was one chieftain who possessed some small understanding of worldly affairs. Addressing his people, he declared: “The lord of this great kingdom aligns his virtue with Heaven. He cultivates the Dao and upholds righteousness, his will unswayed by perversity. Ten thousand blessings sustain him; a hundred spirits guard his realm. How could we, in our folly, muster our forces and defy such supreme goodness? The disasters befalling our lands must surely stem from this. We must swiftly inform the neighboring kings, prepare our tribute, and hasten to offer our apologies.”

Thereupon, one hundred and twenty-five chieftains of the border tribes, along with eighty-four thousand attendants, mounted white elephants and bore offerings of incense, flowers, and jeweled garlands. They galloped into the great kingdom, their breath held as they approached the jade palace. Prostrating themselves before the king, they presented their treasures, their arms trembling, their voices breaking in supplication. Blood streamed from their noses; they tore out their hair in clumps, beating their breasts until their bodies were bruised and swollen. Their cries—half beast, half bird—were unintelligible, and interpreters struggled to convey their remorse.

“We of the borderlands,” they confessed, “do not follow the proper calendar. We are steeped in the turbid qi of the Three Realms, our forms misshapen like the Two Images. We are a mongrel breed, blind to kindness and beauty. Though we draw breath, we are not of the true qi. In our folly, we gave rise to wickedness, our hearts set on rebellion. We allowed our bestial natures to stir, defiling this great kingdom. No sooner had we gathered than Heaven struck us down. Our lands are ravaged by death, eight in ten of our people lost. The poisonous qi has not yet abated, and the calamity grows ever more severe. Those who sought to appease the spirits only invited greater wrath. Heaven has unleashed its fury, and our sacrifices have only worsened our plight. We dare now to beg the Great Heaven for mercy.”

With these words, they cast themselves to the ground, tearing their hair and wailing in despair. The king addressed them: “I have inherited the rule of a virtuous sovereign, entrusted with the governance of all under Heaven. I walk only the path of goodness, seeking nothing beyond. If I do not pity myself, how can I pity you? To me, all beings are as one child; I show no partiality, even to the hidden and obscure. You harbored treachery and came against me, but I remained unaware, leaving your fate to Heaven. I do not condemn you with emotion, nor does Heaven strike you with intent. The punishment you suffer is like spitting at the sky—it falls back upon your own face; like shooting an arrow at the heavens—it returns to pierce your own body. Such is the natural Dao; its principle admits no error.

The incense, flowers, and jeweled garlands you offer are not what I treasure. In this kingdom, we cultivate only virtue and power. As for the grains and silks, the necklaces and ornaments with which your people adorn themselves—these are the trappings of perverse customs, not true valuables. They only burden the body and cling like dust. Why? Because they are mere external adornments, and thus unworthy of esteem. In this kingdom, all people practice forbearance, humility, diligence, and frugality as their adornments. Virtue, precepts, and moral conduct are our incense and flowers; we have no need of your offerings.”

When the barbarian chieftains saw that the king would not accept their tribute, they grew fearful, believing their misfortune would not be dispelled. Weeping, they turned to one another and said: “The king’s refusal to accept our offerings may stem from their meagerness. Let us each present him with a white elephant, that he may show us mercy.”

The king replied: “Jeweled garlands and precious pearls are not what I value; how much less so white elephants, with their foul stench, their ravenous appetites, and their need for vast pastures and herdsmen? They would only burden my kingdom. Even the light and wondrous dragons and phoenixes I do not require.”

The barbarians, overwhelmed with grief and despair, tore out their hair and wailed: “The king will not accept our offerings. We are without fortune and shall surely perish. Better to take our own lives than face this calamity.”

The king instructed them: “Those who seek blessing must serve the Dao with an empty heart. When both body and mind are empty, the Dao too becomes void. Through this emptiness, misfortune is averted. Free from misfortune, one attains blessing. Moreover, those who seek blessing must harbor no desires, no expectations. Your offerings are made with hope, and thus I cannot accept them. In this kingdom, the wise and virtuous adorn themselves with goodness, not with garlands or white elephants.

The king continued: “In this kingdom, we strive only to follow the supreme Great Dao, seeking nothing beyond. You must understand: those who seek blessing must keep their hearts free from perversity, acting with impartiality. They do not chase profit, nor do they shun harm. They do not transform misfortune into blessing, nor do they cling to fortune. Thus they remain free from calamity. Why? Because evil cannot overcome goodness; the inauspicious naturally gives way to the auspicious. Misfortune vanishes of its own accord, and blessing is not something one perceives.

If you seek to avoid misfortune and pursue blessing, you are deluded, unable to grasp the true nature of fortune and misfortune. Your heart turns away from the truth. Why? Because fortune and misfortune share the same gate, rooted in the void.”

chunks.original_text: 是时，诸戎闻大王勅言，不能辨了，请译人译之，敛衽畏惧，不解报答，唯知顶礼，内怀厚媿，跪立不安。 尔时，阴戎之中有一主者，名释头分，请译人宣传，自称是浮提竺乾之王，而作是言：惭愧大天为我等众说希有法。 但以边戎浅识，不究至道，迷远相传，沉滞邪津，历劫未悟，不但今日。 唯愿大天哀愍昏惑。 狂胡无知，情所不了，念达一言，以陈鄙志。 向闻大天示以此国，唯奉大道，无上至真，可得闻乎？ 大王勅言：无上大道常以希声，而聋者不闻。 大道甚微，而盲者不见。 汝等众生，虽有眼目，不能正视； 虽有耳根，不能正闻。 众色纷纷，引汝之明； 邪音凄咽，窒汝之聪。 汝虽有耳目，不异聋盲。 以是因缘，不能闻道。 汝欲闻道，除汝邪闻； 汝欲念道，除汝邪念； 汝欲修道，除汝邪修； 汝欲行道，除汝邪行。 行於正行，慈悲善顺，名为道行。 行此行者，自当闻道； 既得闻道，亦能见道； 既能行道，即能平等，观诸众生与己无异，触物生慈，心不分别。 先建此诚，然后闻道。 尔时，诸戎重复请问：大王无上大道至真妙行以为何宗？ 全生妙用，升入无形，绵绵长存，绝待无累。 愿垂开示，令得解迷。 大王告曰：无上至道以自长生为宗，即此之身而为法身。 以慈悲平等为重，以忍辱柔弱为用，以方便惠物为利，以无为虚白为寂，以智度无碍为通，以道眼观照为达，以弘广容物为虚，以形能随神为无，以无作为自然，以无形为长生。 尔时，诸戎闻大王之言，皆曰未曾有也。 神识虽钝，亦以朦胧，未能尽解，犹亦在疑。 尔时，大王为边戎释除疑结，心开意悟。 於是大王以八月八日为诸戎狄请寒林大师，召集国内出家道士，备陈威仪，为诸边夷七日七夜斋戒悔过。 又却还其所献珍玩，及以璎络。 诸我奉勅，不敢不受，受已转施寒林大师。 大师受已，即分璎络而作二分，一分与众中贫下给使之人，一分与诸戎。 白象还令诸戎，为象着此璎络。 尔时，二万四千大象着此璎络，一时跪拜寒林大师。 象又四散，以鼻绕花，奉上大师。 是给使下人佩此璎络，心生惭愧，皆自叹言：大师平等，一心视物，宝珠璎络，惠施天下人民，及诸白象，顿首辞谢。 寒林大师语曰：无上大道宝，转凡成圣，尚以平等惠利众生，而不恃功。 璎络外饰，邪俗严身，尘滓瑕疵，何足及言？ 外荒杂类，不解献心。 将此施我，我以为受，回以与汝，何用谢之？ 但取勿疑。
chunks.translated_text:
At that time, the tribes of the wilds, hearing the Great King’s decree, could not discern its meaning. They requested an interpreter to convey it, then gathered their robes in awe and trepidation. Unable to respond, they knew only to bow in reverence, their hearts filled with deep shame, kneeling uneasily.

Among the Yin tribes, there was a chieftain named Shitoufen, who asked the interpreter to relay his words. He declared himself the king of Jambudvīpa in India and spoke thus: “We are humbled that the Great Heaven has expounded such rare Dharma for our assembly. Yet we, dwellers of the frontier, possess shallow understanding and have not fathomed the ultimate Dao. Misled by distant hearsay, we have long languished in the ford of delusion, not only today but across kalpas. We beseech the Great Heaven to pity our benighted confusion.”

“These wild Hu, ignorant and unknowing, cannot grasp the truth. We implore you to grant us a single word to express our humble intent. We have heard the Great Heaven declare that this land reveres only the Great Dao, the supreme and most perfect. May we hear of it?”

The Great King replied: “The supreme Great Dao is ever subtle in its silence, yet the deaf cannot hear it. The Dao is most profound, yet the blind cannot see it. Though you beings possess eyes, you cannot gaze rightly; though you possess ears, you cannot hear rightly. A riot of colors distracts your clarity; the wails of false sounds stifle your wisdom. Though you have eyes and ears, you differ not from the deaf and blind. For this reason, you cannot hear the Dao.”

“If you wish to hear the Dao, rid yourself of false hearing. If you wish to contemplate the Dao, rid yourself of false thoughts. If you wish to cultivate the Dao, rid yourself of false cultivation. If you wish to practice the Dao, rid yourself of false conduct. To walk the path of right action—compassionate, kind, and yielding—is called the practice of the Dao. Those who walk this path shall naturally hear the Dao; having heard it, they shall also see it; having practiced it, they shall attain equanimity, perceiving all beings as no different from themselves. Their touch gives rise to compassion, and their minds make no distinctions. First establish this sincerity, then you may hear the Dao.”

Then the tribes again inquired: “Great King, what is the essence of the supreme Great Dao’s most wondrous practice? It preserves life in its perfection, ascends into formlessness, endures ceaselessly, and stands beyond all dependence or burden. We humbly beseech your instruction to dispel our confusion.”

The Great King declared: “The supreme Dao takes eternal life as its essence, and this very body as its Dharma-body. It holds compassion and equanimity as paramount, patience and gentleness as its function, expedient means and beneficence as its benefit, non-action and emptiness as its tranquility, wisdom and unimpeded insight as its penetration, the Dao-eye’s illumination as its attainment, vastness and receptivity as its emptiness, the form’s submission to the spirit as its formlessness, spontaneity as its naturalness, and formlessness as its eternal life.”

Upon hearing the Great King’s words, the tribes all exclaimed: “Never have we heard such! Though our minds are dull and our understanding dim, we have not fully grasped it and remain in doubt.”

Then the Great King resolved the doubts of the frontier tribes, opening their hearts and enlightening their minds. On the eighth day of the eighth month, he invited Master Hanlin for the tribes, summoning all ordained Daoists within the realm to assemble with full ceremonial dignity. For seven days and nights, they performed purification rites and repented of transgressions for the frontier peoples.

He also returned the precious offerings and jeweled garlands they had presented. The tribes said: “We dare not disobey your decree and must accept them.” Having received them, they then offered them to Master Hanlin. The Master accepted and divided the garlands into two portions: one for the poor and lowly attendants among the assembly, and the other for the tribes. The white elephant was returned to the tribes, and they adorned it with the garlands.

At that moment, twenty-four thousand great elephants, wearing the garlands, knelt as one before Master Hanlin. The elephants then scattered, plucking flowers with their trunks and offering them to the Master. The lowly attendants who wore the garlands felt shame arise in their hearts and sighed, saying: “The Master regards all things with impartiality, bestowing the treasure of jeweled garlands upon the people of the world and the white elephants alike.” They bowed their heads in gratitude.

Master Hanlin said: “The supreme treasure of the Great Dao transforms the mundane into the sacred, yet it bestows its blessings upon all beings with impartiality, without claiming merit. These garlands are mere external adornments, worldly embellishments for the body—what are they compared to the dust and blemishes of defilement? You, dwellers of distant lands, do not understand the offering of the heart. You presented these to me, and I accepted them, only to return them to you. Why do you thank me? Simply accept them without doubt.”

chunks.original_text: 至月十五日日中之时，大师与诸道士九万七千人同时受食，毕，漱口宝瓶，余水散洒南西北方，立成云雨，风雷电击。 大师又向三方嘘气，口出金光，远映诸国。 是时，边戎弊疾者，登即差愈，皆於光中遥见大师，如对目前，风雨荡秽，雷音举愆，一切灾□，应时殄灭。 又令八万四千戎夷，悉於光中得见其家。 至月二十日诸戎留后，各遣使者驰入大国，报奏平安，具状所见瑞相如前。 是时，诸戎披发谢过，欢喜道前，顿首伏地，请问大师：不审大师修习何法？ 神变乃尔，自在无碍。 只名大师，复有余号？ 向闻大王勅言，大国之中奉事大道。 不审大师之道与无上大道为一为异？ 蒙昧不晓，唯愿大师广为分别，开示未闻。 尔时，大师弹指謦欬，而告群戎曰：善哉善哉，念法边鄙，哀汝知问，不可思议。 汝当谛听，吾为汝说。 我是玉清天中云宫东台号曰太真，自然虚生，名无上道。 无所修习，但以大慈大悲，应世神变，随心而成，无心故为，不劳於身。 我与大王同时应运，下治兆民、国王，因寄凡胎。 我权号大师，托在寒林。 互为宾实，潜相影响，不一不异，不处中间。 汝等诸夷出生欲界，受质边戎，人心无慈，荒凉弊恶，性便戕害，而不好生。 饮血茹毛，形骸躁腥，神凝浊气，体结偏精。 拔本塞源，抑本崇末。 性重财货，不珍大道。 积劫如此，非独今时。 大道不行，其来久矣。 虽知若此，物有轮转，罪为善本，恶是慈源。 汝等众生向无逆心，终不见我。 大道无私，冤亲不二，以德报怨，不舍大悲。 是故国王请我法众为汝悔过，为汝消灾，慈心平等，无有异念。 故令云雨施散，光音普被。 尔时，大国太帝及以太妃、王子、群臣，先心不知寒林大师与大王重光，同是降神大师。 初来之时，国人大小咸谓大师是凡常之人。 后见大师随心神变，倾国归依，悔过自责，随其富贵贫贱，办诸供具，云萃国内，列满东城，芳春之台，大设斋会，合国士女填塞衢路，车驾纷纷，尘飞雾起。 尔时，大王为施高座，罄国珍玩，装校道场，开发大藏，巨惠谷帛，周穷济乏。 出诸名香，焚烟冲天，结盖凝云。 张设妓乐，惊天聒地。 五岳震动，四海波荡。 春云凉风，调和气序，韶光暧景，同於始春。 长林再花，和莺重发，百鸟翔舞，鱼龙跃鳞，天地吉气以辅王国。 时会大众喜庆无量，行道旋绕，歌颂盈溢，法众步虚，梵赞叹咏。 尔时，大师登座抚几，嶷坐如山，千善为心，万福成体。 大众欣仰，一睹真相，皆发道心，异口同音，百心齐一，合礼道君，愿闻希有。 尔时，无上大道君为众生故，及命国主重光三捻焚香，遥礼云宫大悲天尊，长跪立愿。 第一愿者，道化流行，普天怀德； 二愿一切有生，咸皆悟道； 三愿九夜悲魂，一时解脱； 四愿孤爽无依，咸得受生； 五愿天下太平，百谷成熟； 六愿臣忠子孝，君仁父慈； 七愿四海通同，怨亲和解； 八愿潜胞处壳，俱得生成； 九愿积疾新痾，登即痊愈； 十愿孤露众生，丰衣足食。 尔时，大王陈此十愿，起礼大师，而作是言：唯愿大师为众久处，降迹同凡，不弃尘秽。 大王作此语已，感动天地，虚空雨花，天洒甘露，万变仙乐，鸣玄骇空，天地震动，麟吟凤歌，龙鱼鼓渊。
chunks.translated_text:
On the fifteenth day of the month at noon, the Master and ninety-seven thousand Daoist practitioners partook of their meal together. Afterward, he rinsed his mouth with a jeweled flask, and the remaining water, scattered toward the south, west, and north, instantly transformed into clouds and rain, accompanied by wind, thunder, and lightning. The Master then exhaled toward the three directions, and golden light issued from his mouth, illuminating distant lands. At that moment, those among the border tribes afflicted with illness were instantly cured, and all saw the Master from afar within the light as if he stood before them. The wind and rain cleansed their filth, the thunder’s voice proclaimed their transgressions, and every disaster and misfortune vanished in an instant. He also allowed eighty-four thousand barbarian warriors to see their families within the light.

By the twentieth day, the tribal chieftains each dispatched envoys to hasten into the great kingdom, reporting peace and recounting the auspicious signs they had witnessed as before. Then, the tribesmen, their hair unbound, prostrated themselves in repentance, rejoicing before the Way. They knelt, pressing their heads to the ground, and asked the Master: “We do not know what method the Great Master cultivates. How is it that your divine transformations are so boundless and unobstructed? Are you only called ‘Great Master,’ or do you bear other titles? We have heard the king’s decree that the great kingdom reveres the Great Dao. Is the Dao you practice the same as or different from the Supreme Great Dao? We are ignorant and do not understand. We only hope the Great Master will broadly distinguish and enlighten us on what we have not yet heard.”

At that time, the Master snapped his fingers and coughed lightly, then addressed the assembled tribesmen: “Excellent, excellent! You dwell in remote lands, yet you pity and inquire with such wisdom—this is inconceivable. Listen carefully, and I will explain to you. I am the Supreme Perfected One of the Eastern Terrace of the Cloud Palace in the Jade Clarity Heaven, naturally and emptily born, named the Supreme Dao. I cultivate nothing, yet through great compassion and great mercy, I manifest divine transformations in response to the world, accomplishing them as my heart wills. Without intention, I act, and my body is not wearied. The king and I appeared in the world at the same time to govern the multitudes and kings, temporarily dwelling in mortal form. I provisionally bear the title of Master, residing in Hanlin. We serve as guest and host, subtly influencing one another, neither identical nor different, neither residing in the middle. You, the various tribes, are born into the Desire Realm, assuming the form of border barbarians. Your hearts lack compassion, dwelling in desolation and depravity. By nature, you harm and do not cherish life. You drink blood and consume raw flesh, your bodies restless and foul, your spirits congealed with turbid qi, your forms bound by partial essence. You uproot the fundamental and obstruct the source, suppressing the root while exalting the branches. You value wealth and goods but do not treasure the Great Dao. This has been so for kalpas, not merely in this age. The Great Dao has not been practiced for a long time. Yet though you are thus, all things turn in cycles: sin becomes the root of virtue, and evil is the source of compassion. If you had not harbored rebellious hearts, you would never have seen me. The Great Dao is impartial, making no distinction between foe and kin. It repays enmity with virtue and does not abandon great compassion. Thus, the king invited me and my assembly of practitioners to repent on your behalf and dispel your disasters. With a heart of impartial compassion and no differing thoughts, I caused clouds and rain to scatter and light and sound to universally reach you.”

At that time, the Great Emperor of the kingdom, along with the Great Consort, the prince, and the assembled ministers, had not initially known that the Master of Hanlin and the king were both incarnations of the same divine Master. When he first arrived, the people of the kingdom, great and small, all believed the Master to be an ordinary man. Later, witnessing the Master’s divine transformations at will, the entire kingdom took refuge in him. Filled with remorse, they reproached themselves, and regardless of wealth or poverty, they prepared offerings. The land’s treasures gathered in the eastern city, filling the Terrace of Fragrant Spring. A grand vegetarian feast was held, and the kingdom’s men and women thronged the roads, their carriages stirring dust like mist. Then, the king had a high seat prepared, exhausting the kingdom’s treasures to adorn the ritual arena. He opened the great treasury, bestowing grain and silk to aid the destitute. Exquisite incense was burned, its smoke rising to the heavens, forming canopies of condensed clouds. Music and entertainment resounded, startling the sky and deafening the earth. The Five Peaks trembled, and the Four Seas surged. Cool winds harmonized the seasons, and the radiant springtime warmth returned. Forests bloomed anew, orioles sang again, birds soared and danced, fish and dragons leapt, and the kingdom was blessed with auspicious qi from heaven and earth.

The assembly rejoiced immeasurably, circumambulating in procession, their songs and praises overflowing. The practitioners chanted the *Step of Emptiness*, their Sanskrit hymns resounding in praise. Then, the Master ascended the seat, resting his hand upon the armrest, his presence as steadfast as a mountain. His heart was filled with a thousand virtues, his body formed of ten thousand blessings. The assembly gazed upon him with joy, beholding his true form. All awakened the heart of the Dao, their voices united as one, their hundred minds in harmony. They paid homage to the Lord of the Dao, wishing to hear the rare and wondrous.

Then, for the sake of all beings, the Supreme Lord of the Great Dao commanded the king, Chongguang, to take three pinches of incense, bow from afar to the Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion in the Cloud Palace, and kneel to make vows. The first vow: may the transformative power of the Dao spread, and may all under heaven embrace virtue. The second: may all sentient beings awaken to the Dao. The third: may the sorrowful souls of the nine nights all be liberated. The fourth: may the lonely and unsupported all receive rebirth. The fifth: may the world be at peace and the hundred grains ripen. The sixth: may ministers be loyal and children filial, rulers benevolent and fathers kind. The seventh: may the Four Seas be united, and foes and kin reconciled. The eighth: may those concealed in wombs and shells all be born and grow. The ninth: may chronic and new illnesses be instantly cured. The tenth: may the destitute and exposed all have ample clothing and food.

Then, the king presented these ten vows, rose to bow to the Master, and spoke: “We only hope the Great Master will remain among the people for a long time, descending in form to dwell among mortals, not abandoning the dust and filth.” After the king spoke these words, heaven and earth were moved. Flowers rained from the void, sweet dew descended from the sky, and myriad celestial musics resounded, startling the firmament. Heaven and earth trembled, unicorns hummed and phoenixes sang, dragons and fish stirred the depths.

chunks.original_text: 尔时，道君面门，洞晓真光，遐朗无际，灵音远畅，和适群化，沉尸受生，槁林吐葩，有情无情，含英发花。 道虽不言，诸法已备。 令此众会生希有心，自然而然，吾亦不知其然所。 尔时，诸戎仰视忘瞬，自失其形，兀而不动，犹如枯本。 须臾之顷，云宫天尊降於应身，与诸侍从九亿上真下临青云之上，凝结庆霄，方入万里。 其霄四方，平整如地。 时诸上真列坐其端。 庆霄正中，有紫霞之座，五色云龙，交结负座。 座高八万四千九百九仞。 大悲天尊升此座坐，渐下玄中，去地七百八仞，正临东城，眈眈若虚，湛然不动。 唯见明霞之上，紫光含云，彤彤混然。 众目仰视，不觉天真大师分身上腾，入於云中先所座上。 复入二真，容貌相似。 良久之间，二会寂然，无有音响，真仪不动，犹如金山，光明洞映，不测边际。 大会之中，人及非人，默然不动，心无疲厌，欢喜仰视，乐真观相，倾心注念，不觉有身。 九日九夜，寂无饥渴，身心不动。 尔时，诸戎重睹浮云之上大悲天尊威仪侍从，大惊恐，自拔头发，悔过责己，刀劈其准，遍体血见，踊身自扑，犹如山崩。 睹此希有，求欲舍眼、施头、烧身、破骨，以为供养，声彻大王。 王因出勅而告诸戎曰：无上道法，好生恶杀。 莫以边鄙秽法洿我大邦，烧身谢过，过在身亡，魂神受弊，永失人道。 烧身求道，道存身灭； 灭身求道，道非灭法。 云何灭身而求道乎？ 汝诸夷等入我大国，永不陶化，云何欲闻无上道乎？ 汝欲闻道，应全耳根，不以耳听而闻道也。 汝欲见道，应全眼根，不以败坏之眼而见道也。 汝欲行道，应须全生，不以灭生而行道也。 汝欲行道，先全汝身，不以缺犯之身而行道也。 汝欲怀道，应除十恶，不以五逆之心然后行道。 汝今当知，生不全者，不足闻道； 身不全者，不足学道。 汝诸戎夷，虽非法器，得睹天尊，万劫之后，承此功德，转轮受形，必生大国、有道之邦。 能立誓愿，必不重生鄙野之方。 从今已往，当全汝形，勿以披发烧身破骨，反天逆地，心无慈顺，生死堕邪，永不见道。 诸戎夷等一时拜跪，答大王言：我之风俗，残形灭生，烧身粉骨，浮烟上腾，谓之升天； 或弃尸深水，谓之水仙； 或弃尸林野，以饴禽兽。
chunks.translated_text:
At that moment, the Dao Lord’s countenance radiated with penetrating true light, vast and boundless, its numinous sound resonating afar, harmonizing and transforming all beings. The drowned in death received new life; withered forests burst into bloom. Sentient and insentient alike held their essence and blossomed. Though the Dao spoke not, all dharmas were already complete. This assembly was filled with awe, arising naturally, of itself—even I know not how it came to be.

Then, the various barbarians gazed upward, forgetting to blink, losing their forms, motionless as withered trees. In but a moment, the Cloud Palace Heavenly Worthy descended in response, accompanied by nine hundred million high perfected ones, alighting upon the azure clouds above. A canopy of auspicious mist coalesced, spanning ten thousand leagues. Its expanse stretched level as the earth in all four directions, where the perfected ones arrayed themselves at its edges. At the center of the auspicious mist stood a seat of purple radiance, borne by intertwining five-colored cloud-dragons. The seat rose eighty-four thousand nine hundred and nine *ren* in height. The Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion ascended and sat upon it, gradually descending through the mystery until seven hundred and eight *ren* above the earth, directly over the eastern city, profound and empty, serene and unmoving. Only the crimson glow above the luminous mist was visible, its vermilion hue blending indistinctly. As all eyes looked up, they suddenly beheld the Heavenly Perfected One’s emanation body ascend and enter the clouds, returning to the seat it had occupied before. Then, two true ones appeared, their countenances identical. For a long while, the two assemblies fell silent, without sound or movement, their true forms still as golden mountains. Their radiance shone brilliantly, its bounds unfathomable.

Within the great assembly, humans and non-humans alike sat motionless, their minds free from weariness or aversion. Joyfully they gazed upward, delighting in the vision of the true form, their hearts fixed in single-pointed devotion, forgetting even their own bodies. For nine days and nine nights, they remained without hunger or thirst, their bodies and minds unmoving.

Then, the barbarians beheld once more the Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion upon the floating clouds, attended by his majestic retinue. Overcome with terror, they tore out their hair in remorse, blaming themselves, slashing their noses with blades until their bodies ran with blood. They leapt and flung themselves down as if mountains had collapsed. Witnessing this rarity, they cried out, vowing to offer their eyes, their heads, to burn their bodies, to break their bones as offerings, their voices reaching the king. The king then issued a decree, addressing the barbarians:

“The supreme Dao and its dharma cherish life and abhor killing. Do not defile our great realm with your crude and barbaric ways. To burn your bodies in atonement is to invite ruin—your souls will suffer harm, forever losing the human path. To burn the body in pursuit of the Dao is to seek the Dao through annihilation; to annihilate the body in pursuit of the Dao is to mistake the Dao for a path of destruction. How can one seek the Dao through self-destruction?

You barbarians have entered our great land, yet remain untouched by its refinement. How then can you hope to hear the supreme Dao? If you wish to hear the Dao, preserve the root of hearing—do not seek the Dao through the ear. If you wish to see the Dao, preserve the root of sight—do not seek the Dao through a ruined eye. If you wish to practice the Dao, you must preserve life—do not practice the Dao through death. If you wish to practice the Dao, first preserve your body—do not practice the Dao through a broken or defiled form. If you wish to embrace the Dao, first abandon the ten evils—do not practice the Dao with a heart of the five inversions.

You must now understand: those whose lives are not whole cannot hear the Dao; those whose bodies are not whole cannot study the Dao. Though you barbarians are not vessels of the dharma, having beheld the Heavenly Worthy, after ten thousand kalpas you will inherit this merit. You will be reborn in a great land, a realm of the Dao. If you can vow thus, you will never again be reborn in wild and uncivilized lands. From this day forward, preserve your forms. Do not tear your hair, burn your bodies, or break your bones—such acts defy heaven and earth, lack compassion and obedience, and lead to rebirth in evil paths, forever barring you from the Dao.”

Then, all the barbarians knelt and bowed, answering the king: “In our customs, to maim the body or destroy life, to burn the body to ashes or crush the bones, letting the smoke rise—this we call ascending to heaven. Or to cast the corpse into deep waters—this we call becoming a water immortal. Or to abandon the corpse in the wilds, to be devoured by birds and beasts.”
chunks.overlap_context: these ten vows, rose to bow to the Master, and spoke: “We only hope the Great Master will remain among the people for a long time, descending in form to dwell among mortals, not abandoning the dust and filth.” After the king spoke these words, heaven and earth were moved. Flowers rained from the void, sweet dew descended from the sky, and myriad celestial musics resounded, startling the firmament. Heaven and earth trembled, unicorns hummed and phoenixes sang, dragons and fish stirred the depths.

chunks.original_text: 不贵生身受度，劳於长存。 大王告曰：汝戎狄等以长存为劳，以发肤为累。 我此大国之法，以生灭为累，故求长存无生之道，升入无形，不觉烦恼，不以残形灭生，以远劳累，亦不吹累而累自消亡。 汝诸戎等不舍邪心，具足外道，不除十恶，乐处生死，不遣三毒，人形兽心，不足见道。 勿以戎狄之法秽我大邦。 是时，诸戎直以谢过，不敢拔发，烧身破骨，皆云：不达至道，忽出伪言，以干正直。 只言生而必死，是故升求灭度。 不知无上大道长生无穷，升入无形，绝待无累。 愿垂哀愍，赐以自新。 尔时，大王又勅诸戎：汝野性暗钝，不识道德，自作凶逆，招求罪罚，来此悔过。 大道慈悲，念汝无知。 寒林真师降汝景福，大悲天尊愍汝痴顽。 无上大圣来会我国，万兆无言，倾心注玄，专志大道。 汝诸戎狄轻陈短见，不能安靖，惊触法众，自闹闹他，亡失惠利。 汝但默住，虽不解法，亦得魂识渐渐受润。 是时，诸戎奉大王勅，胡跪默住，不敢动摇，七日七夜。 却后日晡之时，忽见南、西、北方三大天魔各从地司飞空而至，频首真君，顶礼大王，回诃诸戎，怒目切齿，话而言：大王道国，人无三毒，久离十恶，守正修仁，尊道贵德，国无乱臣，家无逆子。 汝诸狂胡，将此罪鬼、行尸之魂，尘秽王国，悔过请福，求闻道乎？ 天科地律，十恶无原； 反逆君父，罪莫大焉。 合粉骨灰身，抽筋裂血，刳剔五藏，剖胆披心，拔出汝舌，不足以谢恶言； 挑出汝目，未足以申恶眼。 汝家国遭灾，子孙亡灭。 一人造逆，误杀万民。 是诸戎夷，身毛皆起，恐怖悲悴，肝胆涂裂，王体挛缩，流汗如雨，气吟口噤，五神无主。 地司执簿以简大王。 王即告诸魔言：无上大道，不间怨亲，於我无伤，云何伐害？ 纵能损我，亦不加报。 大王问诸魔曰：譬如婴儿，或执瓦木，及以锥刀，而伤父母，宁杀之不？ 魔王不也。 王言：我亦如是。 宁损我身，终无有心伤害物命。 况於狂戎智虑微浅，不及婴儿，於我无损。 天以伐之，荼毒狠狈，愍之在心，每为伤痛。 时诸天魔闻大王之言，俱时弹指，皆曰：未曾有也。 相顾而言：大国圣王宽心慈善，大悲及尔，德同造化。 虽暂为王，已具众相，身基万善，千福成心，不久之间，受号天尊。 我等大众已来至此。 此会不久，必当度人。 大道难遇，妙法难闻。 我白大王，求乞停住。 大王知已，即告之言：大道弘广，如空无碍。 此会之中，以道为法。 法无分别，法无起灭，法无见闻，法非内外，亦非中间。 法离生死。 此会之中，淳一无二，皆以一慈悲法。 汝诸魔等，欲诸住者，应如法住。 尔时，诸魔闻大王之言，凛然肃整，还与诸胡参一处立，三日三夜，却后晨朝日初出时，见建木之乡，仙人道士六万八千人俱荫以飞盖，手执花幡，过於龙宫，各持明月神珠、紫琼灵芝，飞空而至，奉上天真。 后有八十一种岛夷之王，皆披五色凤文之衣，各将侍从八千人俱。 是时，诸王各赍神药珍香，一时而至，奉献大王，所谓虎沫七明，龙胎舍利，金晖炳焕，光明耀空。 此舍利者，皆是八琼霜珠化成舍利。 王能服之，身有金姿玉颜。 虎沫七明，龙胎上药，王能服之，身立飞行，千变万化，随心而成。
chunks.translated_text:
The barbarians do not value the deliverance of their living bodies, finding long life a burden. The king declared: “You Rong and Di regard longevity as toil and your own flesh as encumbrance. In this great kingdom’s law, birth and death are the true burden. Thus we seek the Dao of eternal existence without birth, ascending into formlessness, free from affliction. We do not maim the body or destroy life to escape toil—yet without such acts, toil vanishes of itself.

You barbarians cling to perverse minds, following heterodox ways. You do not abandon the ten evils, delighting in the cycle of birth and death, nor dispel the three poisons. Your forms are human, but your hearts are those of beasts—unworthy to behold the Dao. Do not defile my great land with your barbarian customs.”

Then, the barbarians bowed in apology, vowing never again to tear their hair, burn their bodies, or break their bones. They said: “We did not comprehend the supreme Dao and rashly spoke false words, offending the upright. We believed life must end in death, so we sought extinction. We did not know the boundless, supreme Dao grants eternal life, ascending into formlessness, free from all burdens. We beg your compassion and grant us renewal.”

The king then admonished the barbarians: “Your wild natures are dull and ignorant. Unaware of virtue and the Dao, you brought this calamity upon yourselves, inviting punishment. Now you come to repent. The Dao is merciful, pitying your ignorance. The True Master of Hanlin bestows upon you blessed fortune; the Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy pities your foolish stubbornness. The Supreme Great Sage has come to our land. Ten thousand souls fall silent, their hearts fixed upon the mystery, devoted to the Great Dao. Yet you barbarians rashly voice shallow views, unable to remain still, disturbing the assembly, disrupting others and yourselves, forfeiting wisdom and benefit. Remain silent. Though you do not understand the law, your souls will gradually be nourished.”

The barbarians obeyed the king’s command, kneeling in silence without movement for seven days and nights. At dusk on the seventh day, suddenly three great heavenly demons from the south, west, and north flew from the earthly bureaus through the sky. They bowed to the True Lord, prostrated before the king, then turned to rebuke the barbarians, their eyes blazing with fury, teeth gritted, and spoke harshly:

“In the king’s land of the Dao, people are free from the three poisons, long removed from the ten evils. They uphold righteousness, cultivate benevolence, honor the Dao, and revere virtue. The kingdom has no treacherous ministers; households have no rebellious sons. Yet you mad barbarians bring these sinful ghosts and walking corpses to defile the royal land, seeking repentance and blessings, hoping to hear the Dao? Heaven’s statutes and earth’s laws allow no pardon for the ten evils. To rebel against one’s lord and father—no crime is greater! You deserve to be ground to bone-ash, your sinews torn and blood spilled, your five viscera carved out, your gall and heart exposed, your tongue ripped out—still insufficient to atone for your wicked words. Your eyes gouged out—still insufficient to repay your evil gaze. Your homeland will suffer disaster; your descendants will perish. One traitor brings ruin to ten thousand people.”

At these words, the barbarians’ hair stood on end in terror. Their sorrow and dread were so great their livers and gall seemed to split, their bodies convulsed, sweat poured like rain, their breath came in gasps, their mouths clamped shut, and their five spirits scattered in panic. The earthly officials presented their records to the king.

The king addressed the demons: “The supreme Dao makes no distinction between foe and kin. They cannot harm me—why would you attack them? Even if they could harm me, I would not retaliate.”

The king asked the demons: “Suppose an infant, holding tiles, wood, awls, or knives, wounded its parents—would you kill it?”

The demon kings replied: “No.”

The king said: “I am the same. I would rather suffer harm than ever intentionally injure a living being. How much less these mad barbarians, whose wisdom is shallower than an infant’s, who cannot harm me? If heaven strikes them, inflicting cruel suffering, my heart aches with pity.”

Hearing the king’s words, the heavenly demons snapped their fingers in unison, exclaiming: “This is unprecedented!” They looked at one another and said: “The sage-king of this great land is vast in heart and kindness. His great compassion extends even to you. His virtue equals creation itself. Though he is but a temporary king, he already possesses all the marks of perfection. His body is founded on ten thousand virtues; a thousand blessings shape his heart. Soon he will bear the title Heavenly Worthy. We have come to this assembly, which will not last long. He will surely deliver many. The Great Dao is rare to encounter; the wondrous law is rare to hear. We beseech the great king to remain.”

The king, understanding their intent, replied: “The Great Dao is vast and boundless, like empty space without obstruction. In this assembly, the Dao is the law. The law makes no distinctions, knows no arising or ceasing, no seeing or hearing, no inside or outside, nor any middle ground. The law transcends birth and death. In this assembly, all is pure and undivided, united in the single law of compassion. You demons who wish to remain must abide by this law.”

Hearing the king’s words, the demons stood in solemn reverence. They returned to stand among the barbarians for three days and nights. At dawn on the third day, they saw from the land of Jianmu sixty-eight thousand immortals and Daoist masters, each shaded by flying canopies, holding flowered banners, passing over the dragon palace. Each bore luminous moon pearls and purple jade灵芝, flying through the sky to offer them to the Heavenly Perfected. Behind them came eighty-one kings of island barbarians, each wearing robes of five-colored phoenix patterns, accompanied by eight thousand attendants. These kings brought divine medicines and rare incense, arriving together to present them to the great king: the seven luminous tiger foams, dragon embryo śarīra, golden radiance blazing brilliantly, illuminating the sky.

These śarīra were transformed from eight kinds of frost-like jade. If the king consumes them, his body will take on a golden hue and jade-like complexion. The seven luminous tiger foams and dragon embryo elixirs—if the king consumes them, he will instantly gain the power of flight, performing a thousand transformations, shaping all things at will.

Or to cast the corpse into deep waters—this we call becoming a water immortal. Or to abandon the corpse in the wilds, to be devoured by birds and beasts.”

chunks.original_text: 我昔学道，师於长桑道君，见赐神药，服之得仙，后受道要，下治九夷。 闻君降世，助众生喜。 又闻玉清天尊玄立影响，左台上真托栖寒林。 为缘俱会，希音遐震，八表皆闻； 虚光洞空，十方彻照。 故来至此，为敬起居。 尔时，八十一仙说此语已，升身入空，去地百仞，朝礼天尊，空中而住。 尔时，复有东地鬼将，名曰电豕，形长三丈，锯牙凿齿，铜头铁毛，钩舌火气，目似奔星，黑面赤体，牙如鹯足，脚似马蹄，声如击雷，吐气成云。 将眷属六亿余鬼遥闻真人降世为王，以道治国，不挠含生，愿为大国守护郊境，匡赞大王，俱乘黑云浮空而至。 顿首王前，而作是言：臣为鬼方之王，役使游精。 诸有妖魅不宾之者，臣能啖之，生杀在己。 遥闻王国人民慈善，辄率徒众、尘秽王国，敢欲为王而作守护。 若有大圣仙士所在之处，我当给使，晨夕受事。 若有斋讲之所，当率徒众而为外护。 若有外道恶人诽谤善道，衰损法众，我当灭之，令其恶疾，毛发堕落，与其重病。 若有众生於道场中心不端直，邪视念视，我当考之，令此恶人生身受疾，死入地狱，罪延七祖。 若有众生慈善孝顺，念诵经戒，供养大道，以道为心，我当亲近，常当守卫，不令恶鬼得其衰便。 唯愿大王听我徒众卫护道场。 大王告言：善哉善哉，我念众生犹如一子。 於汝亦尔，心无偏党。 幽显虽殊，成愿与汝俱为善识。 尔时，诸鬼欢喜，受语礼谢大王，围绕东城芳春之台，敬礼真人，伏首而住。 尔时，复有火光恶杀六万余鬼，形长三丈，头顶放光，犹如散萤，通身黑色，眼赤如火，手持铁棒，吐气嘘人，立便倒地。 毛竖寒森，闷绝迷乱，鼻口逆血。 闻王有道，以正治国，不损众生，愿为大王威伏恶逆，俱乘黑风从北方来，长跪王前，而作是言：闻王有道，惠润广大，一切幽显，皆沐王恩。 故率徒众，愿为受事，利安王国，守护善人。 若有法会之所，我当外护，摧伏恶魔，正诸邪道。 若有众生毁败道场，潜生毒害，邪心恶眼，来视法众，我当铁棒打杀此人，或拔出其舌，或复令其眉发秃落。 若有众生入道场中，秽身污慢，我当与其癞病，种种灾怪，所在不安，自然恐动。 大王又语诸杀鬼：汝光影毒厉，不可近人，虽有威神，勿行伤夭。 当念众生，扶持善人，愿闻道法，速得转身，成无上道。 诸杀鬼受敕，欢喜而住。 尔时，复有金刚之神八万五千飞空而至，身长丈六，勇健希有，除道神力，余不能过。 翕然而至，莫知所来。 常为大道而作侍卫。 先礼上方大悲天尊，次礼真人，问讯大王，宛如旧识。 而作是言：真仙下世，道化有生，内外相持，人神符会，万邦咸集，边士俱臻。 清浊混淆，真伪无辨。 大圣宽宥，不问昏明。 此会因缘，固非轻小，深宜戒约，以绝不真。 唯愿真王听我说法，正彼道场，惠利善人，变灭凶恶，使人及非人咸尊正道。 大王默而然之。 尔时，金刚即於大众之中暝目一踊，上入青云，奋身而下，地陷石裂，飘气扬沙，尘飞晦日。 怒目成电，啮齿如雷，叱咤千精，驱驰敢违，攘袂鼓肘，抗声大呼，外道亡精，鬼魅失气。 尔时，金刚顾盻而言：我是护法善神金刚力士，侍从大道，受事天真，影卫道场，扶持善人，纠弹罪失，察获奸邪。
chunks.translated_text:
In my past cultivation of the Dao, I studied under Master Changsang Daojun, who bestowed upon me divine medicines. By consuming them, I attained immortality. Later, I received the essential teachings of the Dao and descended to govern the Nine Barbarian Lands. I heard that you have descended into the world to bring joy to all beings. Furthermore, I learned that the Jade Purity Heavenly Worthy has manifested in response, while the Left Terrace Perfected Ones have taken refuge in the Cold Forest. Drawn by this karmic convergence, the resounding echoes of rare harmony shook the eight directions, and all heard it; the empty radiance pierced the void, illuminating the ten quarters. Thus, I have come here to pay my respects.

At that moment, after the eighty-one immortals spoke these words, they ascended into the sky, rising a hundred *ren* above the earth. They bowed in reverence to the Heavenly Worthy and remained suspended in the air.

Then, from the eastern lands, a ghostly general named Lightning Boar appeared. His form stood three *zhang* tall, with jagged teeth and chiseled fangs, a copper head and iron bristles, a hooked tongue and fiery breath. His eyes blazed like shooting stars, his face was black, his body crimson, his teeth like those of a goshawk, and his hooves like those of a horse. His voice thundered like a struck drum, and his exhalations formed clouds. Leading a retinue of over six hundred million ghosts, he had heard from afar that a Perfected One had descended to become king, governing the realm with the Dao, never oppressing living beings. Wishing to guard the borders and assist the great king, they all rode black clouds and arrived floating through the air. Prostrating before the king, they spoke:

"Your servant is the king of the ghostly realms, commanding wandering spirits. Any demons or malevolent beings who refuse to submit, I devour at will, holding life and death in my grasp. From afar, I have heard that the people of your kingdom are kind and virtuous. Thus, I lead my followers to purify your land and humbly offer to serve as its guardians. Wherever great sages and immortals reside, I shall attend them, serving morning and night. At places of fasting and scripture recitation, I shall lead my followers to provide external protection. If any heretics or evil persons slander the true Dao or harm the community of the faithful, I shall destroy them, afflicting them with grave illnesses, causing their hair to fall out and inflicting them with severe maladies. If any beings within the sacred precincts behave improperly—casting sidelong glances or harboring impure thoughts—I shall punish them, causing these wicked ones to suffer bodily afflictions in life and descend into hell upon death, their sins extending to seven generations of ancestors. But if any beings are kind and filial, reciting scriptures and precepts, making offerings to the great Dao, and holding the Dao in their hearts, I shall draw near to them, constantly guarding and protecting them, ensuring no evil ghosts gain advantage over them. I only beseech the great king to permit my followers to safeguard the sacred precincts."

The king replied, "Excellent, excellent! I regard all beings as my own children. To you, I extend the same impartial heart. Though the seen and unseen differ, I grant your wish to join in virtuous recognition."

At that moment, the ghosts rejoiced, receiving the king’s words with gratitude. They encircled the Fragrant Spring Terrace east of the city, bowing in reverence to the Perfected One before prostrating and remaining in place.

Then, over sixty thousand fire-wreathed, murderous ghosts appeared. Each stood three *zhang* tall, their heads radiating light like scattered fireflies. Their bodies were entirely black, their eyes red as flames, and they wielded iron rods. Their breath scorched those it touched, causing them to collapse to the ground, their hair standing on end, their bodies wracked with cold, their senses reeling, and blood flowing from their noses and mouths. Having heard that the king governed with the Dao, never harming living beings, they wished to assist in subduing the wicked and rebellious. Riding black winds, they arrived from the north, kneeling before the king and speaking:

"We have heard that the king governs with the Dao, his benevolence vast and far-reaching, showering all—seen and unseen—with grace. Thus, we lead our followers, wishing to serve, bring peace to the kingdom, and protect the virtuous. At any gathering of the Dao, we shall provide external protection, crushing malevolent demons and rectifying deviant paths. If any beings desecrate the sacred precincts, secretly harboring malice, casting wicked glances at the faithful, we shall strike them dead with our iron rods, tear out their tongues, or cause their eyebrows and hair to fall out. If any beings enter the sacred precincts with defiled bodies or arrogant disdain, we shall afflict them with leprosy, various calamities, and unrest wherever they go, naturally filling them with terror."

The king then addressed the murderous ghosts: "Your radiance and venom are too fierce to approach people. Though you possess mighty spiritual power, do not harm the innocent. Instead, cherish all beings, support the virtuous, and wish to hear the Dao’s teachings, so that they may swiftly transform and attain the supreme Dao."

The murderous ghosts received the decree and remained in joyful compliance.

At that moment, eighty-five thousand Vajra deities descended from the sky. Each stood sixteen feet tall, their strength and valor unmatched, their divine power surpassing all but the gods of the path. They arrived in a sudden rush, their origin unknown. They served as guardians of the great Dao, first bowing to the Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion above, then to the Perfected One, greeting the king as if they were old acquaintances. They spoke:

"As a true immortal descends into the world, the Dao’s transformation nurtures all life. Inner and outer realms align, humans and spirits converge in harmony, and all nations gather, their borderlands submitting as one. Yet purity and impurity mingle, truth and falsehood blur. The great sage, in boundless magnanimity, does not distinguish between the wise and the foolish. This assembly’s karmic cause is neither trivial nor small. It is deeply fitting to enforce strict discipline to eradicate falsehood. I only beseech the true king to heed my counsel: rectify the sacred precincts, bestow blessings upon the virtuous, transform and eradicate the malevolent, so that both humans and non-humans alike revere the true Dao."

The king silently assented.

Then, amidst the great assembly, the Vajra deities closed their eyes and leapt once, ascending into the azure clouds. They surged forward, shaking the earth and splitting stones, whipping up winds and scattering dust until the sun was obscured. Their glaring eyes flashed like lightning, their gnashing teeth rumbled like thunder. With a single roar, they subdued a thousand spirits, driving away any who dared resist. Rolling up their sleeves and flexing their arms, they raised their voices in a mighty cry, causing heretics to lose their essence and ghosts to faint in terror.

At that moment, the Vajra deities glanced around and declared: "We are the Dharma-protecting Vajra deities, attendants of the great Dao, servants of the Heavenly Perfected. We shadow the sacred precincts, uphold the virtuous, expose sins and transgressions, and ferret out deceit and evil."

chunks.original_text: 一切众生莫犯威神。 轻过流血，重衅灭形。 内外整肃，勿使不精。 尔时，会中男女大小咸起恭敬，礼拜金刚，毕具复坐。 尔时，金刚为护法故，调伏幽明二众之心，而说咒曰： 雷火明空，神光朗幽。 毒龙四据，灵虎八周。 头巾七星，足蹈斗牛。 神力列宿，金钩耀精。 元首威兵，腾步虚行。 中绝妖邪，下灭游精。 抽肝出胆，翻肠拔脉。 左斩右锉，前烹后馘。 截妖无原，收束众怨。 啖鬼使者，摧拉生吞。 巫俗歌鼓，饮血食肉。 形膻骨臭，魍魉翻覆。 腥躁秽贱，心形谄讟。 神杵碎首，金刀刎腹。 藏凶匿害，忽来降伏。 左秉金符，右持罪目。 太一金铃，虚皇玉节。 知过不改，悬首自截。 何妖不丧，何精不灭？ 六神不藏，七星裂血。 上有真师，下有金刚。 齐烝降气，口吐灵芒。 饮以月池，以玄霜。 五藏生华，长存不僵。 尔时，大鬼神王四目电光，同为护法，销灭不祥。 守卫道场，察奸纠过，降伏恶人及诸外道、无正信者。 而说咒曰： 神风拂尘，倾拔邪根。 六天丧精，五毒亡怨。 金头铁齿，啖鬼止魂。 挑光烈户，双景曜门。 奔星杀气，朗然无畏。 百脉川流，七经调理。 神安体平，长存不死。 尔时，大鬼神王说此咒已，遥礼上方，后拜真君，告诸鬼曰：汝为道侍卫，守护善人。 说法之师与道无异，不得邪忤真正之气，捉获上闻，万劫无赦。 是时，大鬼神王语会中诸来法众而作是言：我为天帝驱驰，职当归道，扶持新学、入道初门一切男女，摄除乱意，不得邪视，倾听犯戒。 威仪察护，生人同鬼受考。 不但杀鬼，亦以降伏强梁，杀伏邪心，调理生人。 无正信者闻此神咒，应起恭敬。 此神咒者，是天帝威章、自然之文。 诸天魔王、五方鬼将、真官地司助道兴化，守护家国，安靖道场，扶卫善人，皆诵威章，消伏不真，馘灭凶试，摧落邪锋。 外道恶人丧精失气，杂毒魍魉遥闻敬畏。 诸有法会斋讲之处，道场俗舍，我等徒众常在观之，斋戒如法。 丹诚所为，大道降临，福德立至。 身心睽背，为利名声，诚不得已而为斋者，我不守卫，大道不降，魍魉游精，杂毒下鬼，临飨其斋。 轻道慢法，三司纠弹。 道不虚行，要在丹心，非可假求资货贸易。 奉道之子深可慎之。 尔时，鬼将说此语已，却一面立，俨然不动。 尔时，大王车驾西域，迎载父母，百辟卿士皆执花蟠、鼓众伎乐，大备威仪，迎载父母，还芳春之台，焚香顿首。 大悲天尊次礼真师，问讯法众，欢喜委曲。 太帝年老，夫人亦衰。 大王孝顺，瞻视颜色，心恒喜惧。 尔时，真师命其复坐，而告太帝曰：汝之父子名善知识。 汝是紫微之精，下托凡胎，应运为帝。 大王重光是玉清上真，化生汝门。 虽为世帝，形不衰老，皆是自然无上法身。 尔时，真师又语大王言：九夷仙人遗王神药，可以救老。 命汝父母俱时东向，丹水服之。 是时，重光自开宝奁，取药持水，馈於二亲。 父母受，东向长跪而服。 大王取八十杯，分作三分，一分奉上真师，真师不受。 亦与父母，丹水服之。 服之七日，面有金姿玉颜，行步如翔，足才履地，自抑其身，委纵其形，立便飞腾。 又从真师奉受灵书云篆，和神保生三万六千字，晨夕吟诵。 顶浮五气，目有浮光，神彩清澄，威容严丽，馨响通彻，紫气连天，颜貌反婴，素发归玄，出有入无。
chunks.translated_text:
Let no being dare offend the might of these divine spirits. Minor transgressions shall bring bloodshed; grave offenses, annihilation of form. Maintain discipline within and without, and let no laxity arise.

Then, all in the assembly—men and women, young and old—rose in reverence, bowing to the Vajra deities before resuming their seats. At that moment, the Vajra, for the sake of protecting the Dharma, subdued the minds of both the seen and unseen multitudes, and spoke this incantation:

"Thunder and fire illuminate the void; divine radiance brightens the hidden.
Four venomous dragons encircle; eight spirit-tigers surround.
The headband bears the Seven Stars; the feet tread upon Dipper and Ox.
Celestial power arrays the constellations; golden hooks gleam with essence.
The primal sovereign commands the mighty host, striding through the empty sky.
At the center, demons and heretics are severed; below, wandering spirits are extinguished.
Livers are torn out, gallbladders drawn forth; intestines are overturned, veins ripped away.
Left they are slain, right they are crushed; before they are boiled, behind they are beheaded.
Demons are cut off without origin; grievances are gathered and bound.
Ghost-devouring messengers shatter and swallow them whole.
Sorcerers and shamans with their drums and songs, drinking blood and eating flesh—
their forms reek of stench, their bones of foulness; goblins and specters are overthrown.
Rank and filthy, base and restless, their hearts and forms full of deceit and slander—
the divine pestle smashes their skulls; the golden blade slits their bellies.
Those who conceal malice and harm are suddenly subdued.
In the left hand, the golden talisman; in the right, the ledger of sins.
The Great One’s golden bell, the Jade Stave of the Heavenly Sovereign.
Those who know their faults yet do not amend shall have their heads suspended and severed.
What demon shall not perish? What spirit shall not be destroyed?
The Six Spirits shall not hide; the Seven Stars shall split with blood.
Above stands the Perfected Master; below, the Vajra deities.
Together they descend with qi, their mouths emitting divine rays.
They drink from the Moon Pool, bathe in the Mystic Frost.
The five viscera bloom with flowers, enduring forever, never withering."

Then, the Great Ghost-King, his four eyes flashing like lightning, joined in protecting the Dharma, dispelling all misfortune. Guarding the sacred precincts, he examined for deceit and corrected transgressions, subduing evil men, heretics, and all those lacking true faith. He spoke this incantation:

"Divine winds sweep away dust, uprooting the roots of evil.
The Six Heavens lose their essence; the Five Poisons dispel their grudges.
Golden heads and iron teeth devour ghosts and halt souls.
They pierce the radiant door, twin lights illuminating the gate.
Shooting stars carry killing qi, resplendent and fearless.
A hundred meridians flow like rivers; the seven channels are harmonized.
Spirits are at peace, bodies balanced—ever abiding, never dying."

When the Great Ghost-King finished reciting this incantation, he bowed from afar to the heavens above, then prostrated before the Perfected Lord, and addressed the ghosts: "You are the guardians of the Dao, protectors of the virtuous. Those who expound the Dharma differ not from the Dao. You must not oppose the true and upright qi. Capture and report any who do—eternal damnation awaits."

Then, the Great Ghost-King spoke to all in the Dharma assembly: "I am the Heavenly Emperor’s servant, bound to the Dao in duty. I support the newly initiated, all men and women entering the Dao’s first gate. I quell wayward thoughts—you must not cast sidelong glances or heed those who violate the precepts. In vigilance and protection, both the living and the dead shall be examined. Not only do I slay ghosts, but I also subdue the violent, quell wayward hearts, and regulate the living. Those lacking true faith, upon hearing this divine incantation, should rise in reverence. This incantation is the Heavenly Emperor’s mighty decree, the scripture of the natural order. The demon kings of all heavens, the ghost-generals of the five directions, the Perfected Officials and earthly administrators—all assist the Dao’s flourishing transformation, guarding households and nations, pacifying sacred precincts, and protecting the virtuous. All recite this mighty decree to subdue the impure, behead the malevolent, and shatter the blades of evil. Heretics and wicked men lose their essence and qi; venomous specters and goblins, hearing it from afar, bow in awe. Wherever there are Dharma assemblies, fasting lectures, sacred precincts, or lay dwellings, my followers and I shall ever observe them, fasting and maintaining the precepts as prescribed. When sincerity guides the act, the great Dao descends, and blessings swiftly arrive. But those whose hearts are divided, who act for profit or fame, who fast only when compelled—we shall not guard them, nor shall the great Dao descend. Goblins, wandering spirits, venomous ghosts, and lesser demons shall attend their offerings. Those who slight the Dao and scorn the Dharma shall be investigated by the Three Offices. The Dao does not act in vain; it responds only to sincere hearts, not to barter or trade. Disciples of the Dao, take heed."

When the Ghost-General finished speaking, he stepped back and stood motionless, solemn and still.

Then, the Great King’s chariot journeyed to the Western Regions to welcome and escort his parents. The hundred ministers and nobles all held floral banners and played music, their grand procession resplendent in majesty. They welcomed his parents and returned to the Fragrant Spring Terrace, where they burned incense and bowed their heads. The Great Compassionate Heavenly Worthy next paid homage to the Perfected Master, inquiring after the Dharma assembly with joy and solicitude. The Heavenly Emperor was aged, and his consort likewise frail. The Great King, filial and devoted, watched their countenances with a heart ever torn between joy and fear.

Then, the Perfected Master bade them sit once more and addressed the Heavenly Emperor: "You and your son are noble friends in the Dao. You are the essence of the Purple Tenuity, incarnated in mortal form to rule as emperor by the mandate of heaven. The Great King Chongguang is an Upper Perfected of the Jade Clarity, born into your lineage. Though he reigns as a worldly emperor, his form does not age—all is the natural, supreme Dharma-body."

Then, the Perfected Master spoke to the Great King: "The immortals of the Nine Barbarians have bestowed upon you divine medicine to reverse aging. Bid your parents face east and take it with cinnabar water."

At that moment, Chongguang opened his treasure casket, took the medicine and water, and offered them to his parents. They received it, knelt facing east, and consumed it. The Great King took eighty cups, dividing them into three portions: one offered to the Perfected Master, who declined; the others given to his parents, who drank the cinnabar water. After seven days, their faces bore the luster of gold and jade, their steps light as flight. Their feet barely touched the ground, yet their bodies seemed to restrain themselves, yielding to their forms, and they rose into the air. They then received from the Perfected Master the sacred scripture of cloud-seal characters, the *Harmonizing the Spirits and Preserving Life* in thirty-six thousand words, which they recited morning and night. The five qi floated above their crowns; their eyes shone with radiant light. Their spirits were clear and serene, their bearing majestic and refined. Their voices carried with fragrance, piercing and pure; purple qi connected to the heavens. Their countenances reverted to youth, their white hair turned black. They moved between existence and non-existence.

chunks.original_text: 进退之间，合众欢喜，为王作礼。 仰视上方，庆霄忽变青光，以照会东。 复良久间，变成赤光，以照会南。 复良久间，变成白光，以照会西。 复良久间，变成黑光，以照会北。 复良久间，变成黄光，以照会中。 五色光中各有一音，合会流变，寥亮清雅。 五光连云，犹如天虹，皎洁洞彻。 须臾之间，会中真师又放眉间四色光明，以应上方，所谓慈光、悲光、善光、信光。 是时，大会仰视真光，身心忘倦。 又闻八色光明有自然音乐，心音开悟，如服甘露。 是时，诸戎八万余人睹此光已，目冥心闷，犹如大醉，六识闭塞，低倒无知。 尔时，国中有一大臣，名曰守正，见诸夷人低顿无知，前白真师而作是言：我等宿福，生逢有道，得睹真师，见道威神，心开意悟，耳目聪明。 倾心注玄，欢喜忘倦。 不审群夷何故低倒，六识闭塞，神似昏醉？
chunks.translated_text:
Between their advances and retreats, they joined the assembly in joy, offering obeisance to the king. Gazing upward, they saw the azure vault suddenly transform into a radiance of blue light, illuminating the east. After a long while, it shifted into red light, illuminating the south. Again, after a long while, it turned to white light, illuminating the west. Once more, after a long while, it became black light, illuminating the north. And yet again, after a long while, it turned to yellow light, illuminating the center. Within each of the five colored lights resounded a tone, harmonizing and flowing in transformation, ethereal and pure, elegant and refined. The five lights stretched across the clouds like a celestial rainbow, luminous and penetrating.

In an instant, the Perfected Master at the assembly once more emitted from between his brows four hues of radiant light, responding to the heavens above—what are called the Light of Compassion, the Light of Mercy, the Light of Goodness, and the Light of Faith. At that moment, the entire assembly, gazing upon the true light, forgot their weariness in body and mind. They then heard within the eight-colored radiance the music of the natural realm, their minds awakening as if they had tasted sweet dew.

At that time, over eighty thousand of the Rong tribesmen, having witnessed this light, were struck blind and their hearts bewildered, as though deeply intoxicated. Their six senses sealed, they collapsed senseless. Then, a great minister of the kingdom named Shouzheng, seeing the barbarians fallen and insensate, stepped forward and addressed the Perfected Master, saying: "By our accumulated fortune, we were born in an age of the Dao and have been blessed to behold the Perfected Master, to witness the majesty of the Dao, our minds opened and our thoughts awakened, our ears and eyes made keen. Our hearts pour forth into the mysterious, joyful and tireless. Yet we do not understand why these tribesmen lie fallen, their six senses sealed, their spirits as though stupefied by drink."
chunks.overlap_context: cloud-seal characters, the *Harmonizing the Spirits and Preserving Life* in thirty-six thousand words, which they recited morning and night. The five qi floated above their crowns; their eyes shone with radiant light. Their spirits were clear and serene, their bearing majestic and refined. Their voices carried with fragrance, piercing and pure; purple qi connected to the heavens. Their countenances reverted to youth, their white hair turned black. They moved between existence and non-existence.

chunks.original_text: 身负何罪，迷闷失志？ 唯愿真师示所未闻，令众开悟，悉其缘业。 真师答言：大哉，结固业缘不善。 汝当谛听，吾为汝说。 善男子，汝今当知，诸戎狄等初建逆心，招集凶险，上天纵毒，下鬼伐之。 所有骁壮，一时殄灭。 国土空虚，十遗其九。 又悉遭疫，疵疠苦痛，羊马死尽，群戎饥饿，寒冻殒逝，不可计数。 此诸胡鬼，悉诣天帝，言讼其主，冤魂执之，恶业不忘。 是诸戎夷元来悔罪，不图闻道，虽簉生会，死气不消，身神被拘，形空无魂。 以是因缘，使之低倒，迷昏睡熟，为此邪。 尔时，真师说此语已，大众一时顾视诸夷，忽见地烝黑气，平高一丈，蔽覆诸夷。 色如聚墨，黯无分别。 忽闻黑气之中有冤魂吟呴，或大或小，悲鸣凄咽。 是诸戎狄各於睡中见其眷属，相向悲苦，冥目自扑，遍体流血，号咷哮吼，叫唤呜咽，犹如狶鸣，听之惊人。 合众伤痛，弹指泣泪。 真师告曰：善恶之业，生死相随。 譬犹形影，无暂舍离。 道虽愍之，当如其何。 此黑气者名曰阴气，又名杀气，又名怨气，又名尸气，又名浊气。 此是坤母地气，天雨黑灰壅诸夷身，毛发拳缩，形体垢腻。 尔时，真人俯而弹指，大地震动。 须臾之顷，上方庆霄之中微洒甘雨，以沐诸胡，香风下流，以熏诸胡。 六日六夜，目始能开。 一十二日，黑气始消。 群胡形体，悉皆消瘦，无复颜色。 鼻流沸血，两眼垂泪，尸气染身，通体如墨，心眼朦胧，视听不谛，振掉怳忽。 譬如狂人，眼中各见冤家，杂畜诸鬼挥刃驱之。 时诸戎狄举手扪虚，四散迸走，驰出城外。 先所乘象见之惊奔，藏伏草泽，莫知所在。 诸戎狄等见世怨对，眉发秃落，七孔流血，彻骨虫癞，忘失本心，善恶业缘，如声响应，容谷无情，随人所呼。 一切善恶，亦复如是，不回易。 尔时，大王愍之，狼狈自出，道前叩头； 玄师为诸戎夷摄取怨对，说法度脱。 尔时，玄师从座而起，三捻焚香，遥礼上方玉清天尊。 礼讫复座。 须臾之顷，分形万亿，摄取戎鬼，来入会中，为说三宝第一之义，所谓慈悲、忍辱为诸行先。 是诸功德，第一中最。 一切幽明，若离此者，长堕恶道，永不闻法。 又为诸鬼说离生死法，不颠倒、不缚着。 复观真际，空无所有，妄想分别，见有怨亲。 真际既空，怨亲亦空。 是时，真师大混玄澍，沐浴群鬼。 次为诸鬼说无上道法，所谓一道一法，一慈悲力，一受一生，永无变易。 法变易法，永离生死。 既无生死，则无怨对。 诸结缚着之法，永坠生死无底大河，业风所飘，波浪不息。 离此法岸，永没泥滓。 汝诸鬼等欲离生死，应舍大怨，常行一慈。 设复有人衰损我者，我为虚受，不以恶心加报於彼。 如此之法，名离大怨。 若离大怨，则能远离生死之怨。 大事已辨，名之无余。 一切怖畏不能恐动，深根固蒂，不为业风之所倾拔。 譬如大士，不吝财宝，负债速还，有财不收，断吐一切怨家债主，求於道宝，为法施主，不吝尘秽无明之财。 是时，群鬼闻真师说微妙法，悉舍本心，欢喜踊跃，皆发忍辱无上道心。 上元真帝应时心开，洞发慈光，下照群鬼。 是时，群鬼睹此神力，深信道法，晓悟长生常住之道，心无变易，舍离怨对，虚己和敬。 一切异类皆为知识，为欲闻法，求入道场。
chunks.translated_text:
"What sins have their bodies borne to fall thus into confusion and lose their will? We only pray that the Perfected Master reveal what we have not heard, that all may awaken and understand the causes and karmic conditions."

The Perfected Master replied: "Great indeed are the deep-rooted karmic bonds of their unwholesome deeds. Listen carefully, and I shall explain.

"Good man, you must now understand: these Rong and Di tribesmen first harbored rebellious hearts, gathering treachery and peril. Heaven loosed its poison upon them, and the underworld’s ghosts assailed them. All their valiant warriors were annihilated at once. Their lands lay desolate, nine-tenths lost. Then plague struck, bringing suffering and pestilence. Their sheep and horses perished, and the tribesmen, starving and freezing, died in numbers beyond count.

"These Hu ghosts all appealed to the Heavenly Emperor, lodging grievances against their lords. Their vengeful spirits seized them, their evil karma unforgotten. Though these Rong and Di tribesmen later repented their sins, never imagining they would encounter the Dao, even in this secondary birth, their death-qi remained unresolved. Their bodily spirits were bound, their forms hollow, their souls absent. For this reason, they lie fallen, lost in stupor, sunk in deep slumber—thus the work of evil.

When the Perfected Master finished speaking, the assembly turned as one to gaze upon the tribesmen. Suddenly, they saw black qi rising from the earth, leveling at a height of ten feet, shrouding the tribesmen. Its color was like pooled ink, dark and indistinct. From within the black qi came the wails of vengeful spirits, some loud, some faint, their cries mournful and choked.

In their sleep, the Rong and Di tribesmen saw their own kin, facing them in sorrow. They beat their eyes shut, their bodies streaming blood, howling and roaring, their shrieks like the cries of wild boars—terrifying to hear. The entire assembly grieved, snapping their fingers and weeping.

The Perfected Master declared: "The karma of good and evil follows one through life and death, like shadow clinging to form, never parting even for a moment. Though the Dao pities them, what can be done?

"This black qi is called yin-qi, also known as killing-qi, resentment-qi, corpse-qi, or turbid-qi. It is the qi of Kun-Mother Earth. Heaven rained black ash upon the tribesmen’s bodies, their hair curling, their forms filthy and greasy."

Then the Perfected One stooped and snapped his fingers. The great earth trembled. In an instant, from the auspicious clouds above, a fine sweet rain descended, bathing the Hu tribesmen. A fragrant wind flowed down, perfuming them. For six days and nights, their eyes could not open. After twelve days, the black qi began to dissipate.

The tribesmen’s bodies were all emaciated, their complexions gone. Boiling blood flowed from their noses, tears streamed from their eyes. Corpse-qi clung to their bodies, their forms blackened through. Their minds and eyes were dim, their sight and hearing unclear. They trembled and faltered, as if mad, each seeing in their eyes their enemies, along with various beasts and ghosts brandishing blades and driving them forth.

The tribesmen raised their hands to grasp at emptiness, scattering in all directions, fleeing beyond the city walls. The elephants they had once ridden, seeing them, bolted in terror, hiding in the grassy marshes, nowhere to be found.

The Rong and Di tribesmen, confronted by their karmic adversaries, lost their eyebrows and hair, blood flowing from their seven orifices. Worms and sores ate into their bones. They forgot their original minds, their good and evil karma responding like echo to sound, like valleys to voices—devoid of feeling, answering only to what was called.

All good and evil is thus, unchanging.

Then the great king, moved by their plight, emerged in distress and prostrated himself before the Dao. The Mystic Master gathered the vengeful spirits of the tribesmen and expounded the Dharma to liberate them.

At that time, the Mystic Master rose from his seat, thrice pinched incense, and bowed from afar to the Jade Pure Heavenly Worthy above. Having completed his obeisance, he returned to his seat. In an instant, his form multiplied into ten thousand millions, gathering the Rong ghosts and bringing them into the assembly. He taught them the foremost meaning of the Three Treasures: that compassion and forbearance lead all practices, the greatest of all virtues. All beings, seen or unseen, who depart from this will long fall into evil destinies, never hearing the Dharma.

He further expounded the Dharma of liberation from birth and death, of non-inversion and non-attachment. Again, he revealed the true mark of reality—emptiness, with nothing substantial. Discriminating thoughts create the illusion of enemies and kin. When the true mark is empty, enemies and kin are also empty.

Then the Perfected Master poured forth a great deluge of mysterious rain, bathing the multitude of ghosts. Next, he taught them the supreme Daoist Dharma: the One Dao, the One Dharma, the One Power of Compassion, the One Rebirth, forever unchanging. The Dharma transforms the Dharma, forever free from birth and death. Without birth and death, there are no karmic adversaries.

"All the fetters and attachments of the law plunge one into the bottomless river of birth and death, tossed by the winds of karma, its waves ceaseless. Departing from this shore of the Dharma, one sinks forever in the mire.

"You ghosts, if you wish to escape birth and death, you must relinquish great enmity and always practice single-minded compassion. Even if others harm or diminish you, receive it as emptiness, never repaying them with an evil heart. This is called relinquishing great enmity. If you relinquish great enmity, you will distance yourself from the enmity of birth and death. When the great matter is settled, nothing remains. No terror can shake you. Your roots will be deep, your stems firm, unshaken by the winds of karma.

"Like a great being who does not begrudge wealth, swiftly repaying debts, refusing to accept what is owed, cutting off and expelling all vengeful creditors—seek the treasure of the Dao, become a patron of the Dharma, not begrudging the filthy wealth of ignorance."

When the multitude of ghosts heard the Mystic Master’s subtle and wondrous Dharma, they abandoned their original minds, leaping for joy, all arousing the mind of forbearance and the supreme Dao. The Supreme Perfected Emperor of the Upper Primordial, his heart opened, radiated a flood of compassionate light, illuminating the multitude of ghosts.

The ghosts, witnessing this divine power, deeply believed in the Daoist Dharma. They awakened to the Dao of eternal life and abiding truth, their minds unwavering. They relinquished their karmic adversaries, emptied themselves, and cultivated harmony and reverence. All beings of different kinds became their companions, desiring to hear the Dharma and enter the Daoist sanctuary.

Our hearts pour forth into the mysterious, joyful and tireless. Yet we do not understand why these tribesmen lie fallen, their six senses sealed, their spirits as though stupefied by drink."

chunks.original_text: 真人许之。 大众作礼，安坐北面，俨然不动。 是时，诸戎身所患疾登即差愈，亦悉同时各见真人为其说法，身心开悟，皆发道意，俱得解脱。 真师告曰：汝诸戎等，罪业结固，障累未销，未得入会。 且於城外罽帐寥立，专心愿念，各自悔过，一日六时，遥礼城中法会之所。 尔时，阍人名曰慎灵，睹此事已，前进作礼，请问真师而作是言：不审诸夷过去、见在，缘何罪业未得亲近法会之场？ 真师坐而熟告之言：此诸戎狄前身先是此国中人，住在玄谷之阴。 以其前身为大斋主，因散席之次，相共田猎，放火烧山，伤杀禽兽三百余命。 以其承斋之功德不圆，就生於边地，作戎狄主，连今三生。 承此禽庆，故得见我。 向不杀生，应生中国富贵之门。 此戎今生余报未尽，更相率欲起叛心，谋害大国道德天王。 群鬼纵毒，杀其家国，十损其九，冤魂上诉，身神被执。 以是因缘，未得入道，服於正法。 故令住此城外，遥礼法会。 阍人闻说，重问真师：弟子职当守卫，掌知车驾，城门多事，四方辐凑。 奉勅在此，部分回列，使车骑出入，行伍次第，诸听法人教其进止。 为此烦剧，不得入会，礼拜听法。 晨夕愿念，翘想丹尽，唯愿真师哀愍孤露，为作依怙。 真师告曰：汝但有心，专诚笃志。 大道遥鉴，不论内外，及以近远。 大道常以平等济物，边远戎魂，尚沾玄化。 汝以有福，亲卫城门。 一切善人晨夕攸往。 汝善知识，最广余人，今又见我，真善知识。
chunks.translated_text:
The Perfected One granted their request. The assembly bowed in reverence, then seated themselves facing north, composed and unmoving.

At that moment, the ailments afflicting the various barbarians were instantly healed, and each simultaneously beheld the Perfected One expounding the Dharma to them. Their bodies and minds awakened, all aroused the intention for the Dao, and together attained liberation.

The Mystic Master addressed them, saying: "You, the various barbarians, have sins and karmic obstructions deeply entrenched, your hindrances not yet dissolved, and thus cannot enter this assembly. For now, remain outside the city in tents of felt, single-mindedly vowing and reflecting, each repenting your transgressions. Six times daily, bow from afar toward the Dharma assembly within the city."

At that time, the gatekeeper named Shenling, having witnessed this, stepped forward, bowed, and inquired of the Perfected One, saying: "I do not understand—why, due to what past or present sins, are these barbarians unable to draw near the site of the Dharma assembly?"

The Perfected One, seated, explained in detail: "These various barbarians were once people of this very kingdom, dwelling on the shady side of the Dark Valley. In a former life, they served as patrons of a great fast. After the feast, they joined together in hunting, setting fire to the mountains and slaughtering over three hundred birds and beasts. Because the merit of their fast was incomplete, they were reborn in borderlands as barbarian chieftains, continuing thus for three lifetimes. Yet by the residual blessing of those creatures, they have now beheld me. Had they not killed living beings, they would have been born into wealthy and noble families within the Central Kingdom. In this life, their residual retribution is not yet exhausted; they conspire to rebel, plotting to harm the Heavenly King of Dao and Virtue. The multitude of ghosts unleashed their poison, slaughtering nine-tenths of their households and kingdom. The wronged spirits lodged their grievances above, and the spirits of these barbarians were seized. For these reasons, they cannot enter the Dao or partake of the Orthodox Dharma, and so are commanded to remain outside the city, bowing from afar toward the Dharma assembly."

The gatekeeper, having heard this, further inquired of the Perfected One: "Your disciple’s duty is to guard and protect, overseeing the imperial carriages. The city gates are bustling, with all directions converging. By imperial decree, I am stationed here, arranging the ranks, ensuring the order of chariots and cavalry as they enter and depart, and instructing those who come to hear the Dharma in proper conduct. Due to these pressing duties, I cannot enter the assembly to bow and listen to the Dharma. Morning and evening, I yearn with all my heart, longing to the utmost. I only beseech the Perfected One to take pity on this solitary and exposed one, and be my refuge and support."

The Perfected One replied: "As long as you possess the heart, single-minded and sincere in resolve, the Great Dao perceives from afar, making no distinction between inner and outer, near and far. The Great Dao ever aids beings with impartiality; even the distant barbarian souls are touched by its mysterious transformation. You, by virtue of your good fortune, personally guard the city gates. All good people come and go morning and evening. You have the most extensive connections with others—now, having beheld me, you have found a true and good spiritual companion."
